message: I only heard about Quora through a friend of the founders who worked at Google
but it seems super popular now
I find myself really spending a bunch of time on there
probably because the quality is so high
It's that same kind of thing I want to achieve with our stars.  I feel happy when someone stars my message :)
however, the quality of Convore is questionable
Me too :)
It's a much more positive experience
see I read the content
When someone upvotes my answer, it's almost like a dopamine hit or something, it makes me happy
there you go
but i hope that the higher quality topics and content wont go away either
They're really good about making you feel good about putting quality content into the system
I think it's always effective to focus on one problem, and Quora does that well
but I'm shy about actually contributing
@ericflo i agree its interesting to now that the site was designed for quality content
yeah i worry about that a bit too....
wha? I like the silliness of convore
no no dont get me wrong i do too
I want them to hire quality designers
i think its cool that they are building a better wikipedia...
ie
better as in EASY to respond
@felix Yeah, it's nice that you don't have to know all the rules or spend a bunch of time, you just answer what you can.
I feel like every single aspect of Quora's design is a failure
Then again, Wikipedia makes people to learn their crazy markup language and they seem to be doing just fine.
I think they are going to have a fairly large problem when it comes to getting "normal" users to use it.  It's big and complicated and there are a lot of moving parts.

I was hardcore into QA sites (one in particular, actually) but Quora really failed to grab my attention. I'm not sure what it is, I just didn't fall in love with it. This is kind of weird, but these days the only sites I really really like need to have a lot of personality and some whimsy :)
it's a bit of a catch-22, since to push the devs to make it friendlier they need people who aren't tech-savvy to complain, but those people aren't joining because, well, the learning curve
I just saw a friend of mine's dad who's a music bigwig (former sony music VP) signed up, wonder if it's taking off in non-technical fields
I hope that's true; if the non-techies finally get in there it would add a lot of potential, but as many others have said, it might not happen because of the learning curve

There's an issue with Quora when people ask questions seeking subjective answers. The vote up/down system is immediately useless for anyone looking for the facts. Just because a lot of people agree with something doesn't always mean it's right. I work in design so a lot of the QA's I looked at were purely subjective. It's bad to see good opinions (radical or not) be pushed to the bottom out of consensus. That's why I like the more conversational feel to things here.

@gggritso yep - that's where the issue of subjective answering comes in - the knowledge shared isn't definitive. Vark is also more conversational and subjective in nature and I find that more useful. It's like what google is to wolfram alpha maybe? Hard to describe, but Quora isn't the right place to ask "what's the best burrito in SF', for example.

@davisp so wikipedia may attract writers who are genuinely interested in the subject (as the information shines) while quora may be more about showing how clever one is (profiles shine). To be blunt, I find a lot of what I read on quora beard-strokey and smug rather than direct, explanatory and communicative.
@davisp lol yeah, I haven't thought about it too thoroughly, but all the above are my first impressions.
(I often see the interesting Flickr and popular Instagrams as cliche, for example, but that makes me a minority, maybe?)
after connecting on my laptop months ago i've never been able to log back into my account on any other computer
i'd spend more time on quora if there facebook connect didnt fail across two computers

But re: Quora vs Wikipedia, I think its a difference in format. Wikipedia has no question. There's nothing required to prompt me to write about http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toilet_paper_orientation or http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Care_Bears If I feel like "writing" on the subject I just go and create/edit the page.
But that's more on technical grounds
Ie, not well cited etc etc
Well, not limited, but that seems to be a differentiator

wikipedia runs on the premise that someone else will eventually consider my soap doll article valuable, where as quora seems to flip things round in that the soap doll info isn't important until someone asks for it
@Spencer And I think that's a good observation about the profiles being public and hence a reason for constructing an image

But what I my main point would be that Wikipedia doesn't require there to be an event for a contribution. Quora seems limited by the fact that I can't just write about soap dolls for a couple hundred words.
Not quite no

Ah yes- the 'this is interesting because other people say so' phenomenon. See also: 'interesting' on Flickr, 'popular' on instagram, 'trending topics' on twitter and '38 of your friends like this' on facebook. I see why this is useful, but it sure does push niche interest to the bottom.
(my brain hurts)
The social filtering is interesting, but not the same phenomenon
@spencer I would say to an extent sorta kinda
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toilet_paper_orientation
And it includes pictures of cats attacking toilet paper.
It can be suggested for deletion of coures
ie, you can't just create a wikipedia article on _anything_

Consider the soap doll example, on wikipedia I go write about soap dolls. On quora I wait for someone to ask about soap dolls. Wikipedia allows for more impulsive type "I want to write" type interaction
@davisp can't people suggest your wikipedia article be deleted due to lack of relevance/interesting?
Sure you can
I mean to say, I'm not super familiar with the wikipedia editorial policies, but they have an article on toiler paper orientation for example
Quora is a great tool to explore knowledge.

My very unscientific test of Quora's quality: best questions in algorithm. The first is a newbie complexity question, the second is about a system call implementation. Neither is even about algorithms. I don't think Quora is going to be my preferred source for information about algorithms.

Quora is such a timesink ... as will probably convore be one in the future for me. Could we please finally move to 48h days? Perhaps I can finally find some time again for all those great services out there :-P

What I don't like about quora right now, is the lack of gratification. Sure, your answer is up-voted and it gets listed higher in the answers-section, but I really miss achievement points :-P
Ugh, Quora is a sinkhole and will go the way of Yahoo! Answers in no time. It's just a forum of opinions. Nice try but no.
kind of a boring website
Anyone here?

@leah I know this is a two-weeks old response, but I like how Convore feels informal. Quora actively stymies informal debate and casual discussion, which is not what I want everything in my life to be like. :)
Quora is like a serious beard. Convore is like a funky goatee. Whatever that means.

I tried Quora for a while. I liked it initially, but I soon grew to hate the elitism. It annoys me that anything controversial is looked down upon even if it's the right answer. That's why I'm on Convore, it's much more informal and I can help people without worrying so much about how I structure my replies. By nature I'm more jokey, which doesn't fit with quora.
#quote
I'm curious about how Convore can allow for discovery, and reduced barrier to entry, a la Aardvark.
@muraii Me too

When I saw Convore announced, especially having looked at Pownce though not using it much, I wondered if this might be a piece I've been looking for. I'm trying to figure out how to enable collaboration that's high-fidelity, allows for concurrency and delayed responses, and allows for easy discovery. Like Math Overflow with easy transfer and linking of content between affiliate services, plus Convore for the real- or near-real-time conversation, and something that allows for, say, real-time document creation supporting LaTeX. Add an Aardvark-like discovery mechanism, and maybe it's pretty close to perfect. Except that's a very, very tall order, filled with lots of Hard Problems. I like the vein of @Leah's projects, though; and I like that it's Django (trying to find time to pick up Python on the way to picking up Django). </semi-rant>

@spencer I like how you phrase that about subjectiveness in terms of their answers. Personally the only interesting bits from quora that I've seen are basically "well thought out HackerNews comments."

@spencer I like your use of "conversational" since I feel that Quora isn't really a conversation at all; to me it seems to be more like a knowledge repository (the knowledge being answers to questions)

To those asking about it being invite-only, http://www.quora.com/Why-has-Quora-gone-back-to-invite-only-access-recently-Jan-2011 suggests that there are no invites needed for some countries (e.g., US), but that there are for others.
I had my Quora account blocked because some admin arbitrarily decided my name wasn't good enough.
@AroonUp Then why don't you contact their moderation team?
@AroonUp There is an email Id for that department
@AroonUp Is Aroon your real name ? Or Arun? Quora has some restrictions about Names.They need full names for profile creation.
@AroonUp there have been quite a few cases ...
Reviewer here if anyone has any questions...
hello Quora folks
Well I am not a 'tech' person per se and I typically review questions on my topics which are more broad and on average I am a little disappointed.
I have a question - do you find that the overall quality of the questions that are submitted is high?
in the time that you've been a reviewer, do you think the quality has decreased dramatically?
I just happen to review Q and A's as I go
well a lot. You cant call it volunteering because I am USING (like you) while I review
well, sure, but there's a difference between using Quora casually, and spending time specifically to improve the overall quality of the site
I know Charlie personally so it feels a little different
for instance, you browse questions from time to time
But more regular users can help by editing the questions to make them more appealing
not dramatically. I am happy to see so many more questions on rarer topics.
despite quality problems
that's pretty great, actually
so do I
how much time do you volunteer to Quora?

@AroonUP what problem are you having

Hi -- @JohnHillman I think that Convore is a perfect match for Quora, because it allows the realtime conversation that is  lacking on Quora.
I advertised it on my profile but it seems that very few people see this as a necessity. Got any ideas why?
https://convore.com/quora/

I'm not sure, I only joined convore about 20 days ago but and it was because a Reviewer created a group (not this one I might add) it was for the explicit reason of communicating with regular users but no one joined it.
The Reviewers on Quora have and use a Quora based real time chat, it may end up being a part of Quora but I cant say for sure.
@JohnHillman I cannot post on Quora, got a message awhile back that they thought my name was fake.
@JohnHillman I think it takes a bit of effort to really get a group going. I'm on the Convore dev team and we're working on making it easier to get people into groups and chatting.
@leah thanks, did not mean to judge convore I am enjoying it. One thing i don't like a lot if that I get notifications for all other 'tech' topics even though I just want to see Quora at the moment.
@aroonup, have you emailed moderation@quora.com explaining the situation? send me a message on Quora I will see what I can do: http://www.quora.com/John-H-Hillman-V

I created a group here just to talk about philosophy and advertised it on my profile page but no one took up the offer. I think it would be nice if Quora had realtime chat for users, but I kinda like the idea of the chat being outside of Quora, so that people would be uninhibited about what they say about Quora, as you can see other comments here are  (uninhibited).
